texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Regular users of Python's package tools like  pip  or  easy_install  are probably familiar with the  PyPi  repository. It's a one-stop-shop to learn more about available Python packages and get them installed on your server.
texts.text: Regular users of Python's package tools like  pip  or  easy_install  are probably familiar with the  PyPi  repository. It's a one-stop-shop to learn more about available Python packages and get them installed on your server.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, certain folks may find the need to host a local PyPi repository for their own packages. You may need it to store Python code which you don't plan to release publicly or you may need to add proprietary patches to upstream Python packages. Regardless of the reason to have it, a local PyPi repository is relatively easy to configure.
texts.text: However, certain folks may find the need to host a local PyPi repository for their own packages. You may need it to store Python code which you don't plan to release publicly or you may need to add proprietary patches to upstream Python packages. Regardless of the reason to have it, a local PyPi repository is relatively easy to configure.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You'll need to start with a base directory for your PyPi repository. For this example, I chose
texts.text: You'll need to start with a base directory for your PyPi repository. For this example, I chose

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . The directory structure should look something like this:
texts.text: . The directory structure should look something like this:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: , you'd make a structure like this:
texts.text: , you'd make a structure like this:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once you have at least one package stored locally, it's time to configure apache. Here's a snippet from the virtual host I configured:
texts.text: Once you have at least one package stored locally, it's time to configure apache. Here's a snippet from the virtual host I configured:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
DocumentRoot /var/pypi/
ServerName pypi.example.com

Options +Indexes

RewriteEngine On
RewriteRule ^/robots.txt - [L]
RewriteRule ^/icons/.* - [L]
RewriteRule ^/index\..* - [L]

RewriteCond /var/pypi/$1 !-f
RewriteCond /var/pypi/$1 !-d
RewriteRule ^/(.*)/?$ http://pypi.python.org/$1 [R,L]
texts.text:
DocumentRoot /var/pypi/
ServerName pypi.example.com

Options +Indexes

RewriteEngine On
RewriteRule ^/robots.txt - [L]
RewriteRule ^/icons/.* - [L]
RewriteRule ^/index\..* - [L]

RewriteCond /var/pypi/$1 !-f
RewriteCond /var/pypi/$1 !-d
RewriteRule ^/(.*)/?$ http://pypi.python.org/$1 [R,L]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The last set of rewrite directives check to see if the request refers to an existing file or directory under your document root. If it does, your server will reply with a directory listing or with the actual file to download. If the directory or file doesn't exist, apache will send the client a redirection to the main PyPi site.
texts.text: The last set of rewrite directives check to see if the request refers to an existing file or directory under your document root. If it does, your server will reply with a directory listing or with the actual file to download. If the directory or file doesn't exist, apache will send the client a redirection to the main PyPi site.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Reload your apache configuration to bring in your new changes. Let's try to download the
texts.text: Reload your apache configuration to bring in your new changes. Let's try to download the

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: tarball from our local server in the example I mentioned above:
texts.text: tarball from our local server in the example I mentioned above:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ curl -I http://pypi.example.com/simple/pip/
HTTP/1.1 200 OK

$ curl -I http://pypi.example.com/simple/pip/pip-1.0.2.tar.gz
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
texts.text:
$ curl -I http://pypi.example.com/simple/pip/
HTTP/1.1 200 OK

$ curl -I http://pypi.example.com/simple/pip/pip-1.0.2.tar.gz
HTTP/1.1 200 OK

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've obviously snipped a bit of the response above, but you can see that apache is responding with 200's since it has the directories and files that I was trying to retrieve via curl. Let's try to get something we don't have locally, like
texts.text: I've obviously snipped a bit of the response above, but you can see that apache is responding with 200's since it has the directories and files that I was trying to retrieve via curl. Let's try to get something we don't have locally, like

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ curl -I http://pypi.example.com/simple/kombu/
HTTP/1.1 302 Found
Location: http://pypi.python.org/simple/kombu/
texts.text:
$ curl -I http://pypi.example.com/simple/kombu/
HTTP/1.1 302 Found
Location: http://pypi.python.org/simple/kombu/

texts.text: so it will refer our Python tools over to the official PyPi repository to get the listing of available package versions for

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once your tools are configured, try installing a package you have locally and try to install one that you know you won't have locally. You can add
texts.text: Once your tools are configured, try installing a package you have locally and try to install one that you know you won't have locally. You can add

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: to watch it retrieve different URL's to get the packages it needs. If you spot any peculiar behavior or unexpected redirections, double-check your mod_rewrite rules in your apache configuration and check the spelling of your directories under your document root.
texts.text: to watch it retrieve different URL's to get the packages it needs. If you spot any peculiar behavior or unexpected redirections, double-check your mod_rewrite rules in your apache configuration and check the spelling of your directories under your document root.
